briefOverview: A personal revelation to Emma Smith outlining her calling, responsibilities, and promises, with closing counsel addressed broadly to all believers.
summary: The Lord addresses Emma Smith as an “elect lady,” assuring her forgiveness and promising preservation and an inheritance if she remains faithful. She is counseled not to murmur about things withheld, to comfort and support Joseph Smith in his afflictions, to accompany him and serve as scribe when needed. She is to be ordained to expound scripture and exhort the church as the Spirit directs, to receive the Holy Ghost by the laying on of hands, and to devote time to writing and learning. She is urged to seek spiritual things rather than worldly ones and is appointed to compile sacred hymns because the “song of the righteous is a prayer.” Finally, she is called to rejoice, keep covenants, continue in meekness, avoid pride, and keep the commandments to obtain a crown of righteousness, with the closing assertion that these teachings are the Lord’s voice to all.
externalContext: This revelation is dated to 1830, early in the organization of the Church of Christ (later The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints), when roles were forming and the need for scribes and teachers was acute. Emma Hale Smith, newly baptized in 1830, was the wife of Joseph Smith and participated closely in early church events. She later compiled the church’s first hymnal (published in 1835), fulfilling the directive to select sacred hymns. The phrase “elect lady” was later invoked when Emma was named president of the Nauvoo Relief Society in 1842. Practices such as conferral of the Holy Ghost by the laying on of hands were part of early Christian patterns the early Latter-day Saints sought to emulate.
externalReferences: The address to an “elect lady” recalls 2 John 1:1, where a Christian woman is similarly honored, suggesting a recognized female leadership or dignity in the early church. Receiving the Holy Ghost by the laying on of hands resonates with Acts 8:17. The instruction to compile hymns and the affirmation that the Lord delights in song align with New Testament exhortations to sing psalms and spiritual songs (Ephesians 5:19; Colossians 3:16). Promises of a “crown of righteousness” and seeking a better, heavenly inheritance echo 2 Timothy 4:8 and Hebrews 11:16, while calling believers “sons and daughters” parallels 2 Corinthians 6:18.
practicalQuestions: How can I support and comfort those bearing heavy responsibilities in my community or family?
What does it look like for me to “lay aside the things of this world” and prioritize spiritual learning today?
In what ways can I use music and worship to draw closer to God?
How can I cultivate meekness and guard against pride while fulfilling my responsibilities?
Which covenants have I made, and how can I more fully cleave to them in daily choices?
uncertainAreas: The scope of “unto them is his calling” (v. 9) is unclear—whether it refers solely to Joseph or to Joseph and others. The precise meaning of “elect lady” (v. 3) and the nature of “ordination” for Emma (v. 7) are not fully defined in the text. The specific “things…withheld” (v. 4) are unspecified. The phrase “this is my voice unto all” (v. 16) raises interpretive questions about how universally to apply counsel originally given to Emma personally.
